> Forgiveness and love of one’s enemies are also religious ideals that originate in the New Testament and were sometimes given a supererogatory interpretation in later Church doctrine.
> 
>  It is, for example, not clear whether “love thy enemy” is a precept or a supererogatory counsel.

Yeah no, this is the clearest thing in the whole canon. As much as we don't want to fulfill it, this is absolutely an obligation. To claim otherwise goes against the theme of the entire new testament. Actually the old too, despite the greater amount of tampering with the text trying to negate it.

Also, there is no way you can exceed the expectations, because they aren't attainable by normal humans to begin with, as your last quote explains. You cannot go beyond perfect, or it would not be perfect.

Also, there is no way you can exceed the expectations, because they aren't attainable by normal humans to begin with, as your last quote explains. You cannot go beyond perfect, or it would not be perfect.

post.body:
Summary for reflection: there are some things that are obligations, and then there are actions that go beyond that (supererogatory acts) which are even better but not required ("going the extra mile"). 

I've found this distinction important to make at times as frequently some people expect as obligation what is already beyond what is necessary ("the most I am capable of is what I must do"), or may go to the other extreme of not defining minimum obligatory acts in certain situations, which might create a sense of guilt of not having fulfilled moral requirements. 

Certain supererogatory acts might be wrong to do as they are beyond one's capacity or calling. Certain things may be made out to be obligations which are not obligations.

What is obligation or supererogatory may be specific to the individual.

[Supererogation - Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/supererogation/)

> Most ethical theories maintain some form of this two-tier structure of the moral system, although admittedly in different versions and emphases. But this double role of normative discourse inevitably raises the idea of supererogation, the category of actions that are praiseworthy (either in creating good states of affairs or in reflecting a particularly virtuous trait of character) yet at the same time not obligatory. Supererogation lies at the intersection of the axiological and the deontic, the ‘good’ and the ‘ought’. Since moral theories of the past (like Aristotle, Kant and utilitarianism) all appeal in some form to both deontic and axiological concepts, the scant and cursory discussion of supererogation in those theories is all the more surprising.

> The most notable exception to this historical generalization is the long-standing and elaborate Roman Catholic doctrine of opera supererogationis. The general background of this doctrine is the recognition of the two faces of morality under the concepts of “precepts” and “counsels.” The origins of this distinction go back to the New Testament, in which to the question what one should do to gain eternal life, Jesus replies: “if thou wilt enter into life, keep the commandments,” but adds “if thou wilt be perfect, go sell what thou hast and give to the poor and thou shalt have treasure in Heaven” (Matthew xix, 16–24). Beyond charity, the Church Fathers detected in the New Testament two additional evangelical counsels, chastity and obedience: taking a wife is no sin, but virginity has a superior value; the life of an ordinary Christian cannot be blamed, but that of absolute monastic dedication is far better. Forgiveness and love of one’s enemies are also religious ideals that originate in the New Testament and were sometimes given a supererogatory interpretation in later Church doctrine.

> The Old Law of the Old Testament is regarded by early Catholic thinkers as reflecting the rigid and minimal demands of religious morality, typically formulated in the negative terms of prohibitions and precepts (the violation of which entails punishment). The New Law, that of the New Testament, sometimes called the Law of Liberty, leaves the individual free to pursue more edifying ideals of perfection. Tertullian called this freedom licentia. According to the Catholic doctrine, the special merit of supererogatory acts accredited to their agent can be used both for that individual’s own salvation and for the salvation of others. The “superabundant merit,” most typically collected by the actions of Jesus and the saints, who far exceeded what was required for their own salvation, is deposited in the Spiritual Treasury of the Church to be disposed by the Pope and the bishops for remitting the sins of other, ordinary believers. This is how the institution of Indulgences gradually developed in the late middle ages: sinners could buy the remission of their sins, first by joining the Crusades and later by contributing money to the coffers of the Church.

> The most articulate exposition of the doctrine of supererogation in the Christian tradition is found in Thomas Aquinas (Summa Theologica). Thomas mentions two distinct sources of merit of supererogatory behavior. On the one hand supererogation serves as a more expedient or guaranteed way of achieving everlasting life; on the other, it is intrinsically good in being aimed at higher ends than the mere fulfillment of the commandments. Precepts are universal in their scope, whereas counsels are addressed to the few who have the capacity and inclination to pursue the life of perfection. For Thomas, the open-texture character of the counsels of supererogation is what makes the morality of love superior to the authoritarian nature of the strict law. But Thomas does not draw a clear borderline between duty and supererogation. It is, for example, not clear whether “love thy enemy” is a precept or a supererogatory counsel. It is similarly unclear whether beneficence (almsgiving) is a duty or lies beyond duty. Nor is the role of virtue in demarcating the supererogatory from the obligatory explained. Thomas says that both natural law and positive law prescribe acts of virtue in general but they do not prescribe every specific virtuous act (except for those that promote the social good of justice and peace). And as for divine law, it prescribes also other, non-social actions that belong to the relations between man and God but leaves those actions of perfect virtue to the realm of supererogatory counsel.

(Note: Not sure how much Catholics agree with some of the following, how much the "institution of indulgences" was "commericialized", but this seems to accurately portray the views of the "Reformers")

> The Catholic doctrine of supererogation met with an extremely fierce opposition in the times of the Reformation. Luther, Calvin and Anglican theologians attacked both the theory of “super-meritorious” actions and the corruption involved in the commercialization of the institution of indulgences for which the theory served as a cover. No human being, not even a saint, can do all that is strictly required as a duty, let alone hope to go beyond that. The way to salvation is not through “works” but through divine grace alone (Luther 1957). Even the most dramatic acts of martyrdom and self-sacrifice, which served the Catholics as paradigm examples of supererogation, are strictly speaking obligatory. Protestant ethics thus undermines the distinction between the two faces of morality: on the one hand, normative requirements cannot be defined in terms of rules fixing minimally prescribed behavior; on the other hand, every religiously good behavior is obligatory. Saints and sinners are equally dependent on God’s grace for their salvation. Paradoxically, it may be noted, exactly because human actions can never fulfill God’s commandments, divine grace is never due or ethically called for: it is typically supererogatory, a free gift of God!

parent.body:
I will also, as many others here do, encourage you to start with the gospels.  I will suggest John first, as it portrays Jesus as God, while the others were tailored a bit more for the Jews or the Greeks.  

My 2 cents, for what theyre worth, is that that Jesus only seems like a nice guy until you actually read what he said and did.  Dude wove himself a bullwhip then raided the temple to drive out the merchants that had set up shop there.  Told off the pharisees to their faces so bluntly and so often they tried to kill him for it numerous times.  Jesus was not your modern "nice guy."

Edit: Also, if youre of a more philosophical bent, anything CS Lewis wrote is pretty good.  Still, regarding doctrine, I would say, dont listen to what people say, look at what the Bible says.  Take it back to the original Greek and Hebrew with a Concordance.  Our modern society and modern churches have spent the last several centuries twisting its teachings into what people think Christianity is today, but the original texts are still there to be read for themselves, no matter how much people try to twist them.
parent.body_html:
I will also, as many others here do, encourage you to start with the gospels. I will suggest John first, as it portrays Jesus as God, while the others were tailored a bit more for the Jews or the Greeks.

My 2 cents, for what theyre worth, is that that Jesus only seems like a nice guy until you actually read what he said and did. Dude wove himself a bullwhip then raided the temple to drive out the merchants that had set up shop there. Told off the pharisees to their faces so bluntly and so often they tried to kill him for it numerous times. Jesus was not your modern "nice guy."

Edit: Also, if youre of a more philosophical bent, anything CS Lewis wrote is pretty good. Still, regarding doctrine, I would say, dont listen to what people say, look at what the Bible says. Take it back to the original Greek and Hebrew with a Concordance. Our modern society and modern churches have spent the last several centuries twisting its teachings into what people think Christianity is today, but the original texts are still there to be read for themselves, no matter how much people try to twist them.

post.body:
Raised Christian. Became an atheist when going through high school and college. 

Now after seeing all this covid and the great reset / new world order stuff going on and how the Bible seems to have warned about this stuff... I feel like I am being pulled back into it.

The reason I'm asking for good sources is because it seems to me that a lot of Christianity has become "weak". Too tolerant, liberal, and afraid to stand up for their faith. Too "nice guy - ish" if you know what I mean.

post.body:
Pride is one of the "seven deadly sins" and biblically has no association to the rainbow. Thus I've dubbed the past several years June, in which the rainbow becomes plastered everywhere, as Promise Month in order to spread the good word of a promise made by God never again to flood the earth. To take a hand made symbol given to us by God and pervert it into something that represents something He calls abominable is a horrible thing. In my opinion not even the cross is as intimate as the rainbow, as the cross itself had no power on its own, but the blood of Christ was what brought redemption, not two pieces of wood. The rainbow, however, was hand crafted by the Father for us.

I say wear the rainbow this month and emblazon it with the word PROMISE. When people ask you why it doesn't say pride, explain to them, and spread the gospel a bit. Take back what was given to those who follow the way of truth.

post.body:
Last year ago there was the nether update - which created an entire new aspect to the game. At the least it could be considered an ok update and at the best it could be considered a great one. A year has passed without any updates - and the update to soon be given is essentially nothing. The hype for a cave update has been greatly disappointed. It may not be until Christmas until what will by then be considered a moderate update is given. 
The game is perhaps the most popular that has existed. It might have not been even supposed to be still alive. It was dying. And then Swedish man - yes Swedish man and Swedish man alone. He was the one who made flappy bird popular - his influence is undeniable. And later on there was dream - who also gave a huge boost to the game. I don’t think it will see such growth ever again.

parent.body: In all honesty, if you're looking for solid new content, modding is the way to go. The amount of quality content from mods like The Aether, Twilight Forest, Tinker's Construct, Quark, etc is incredible, to the point where choosing to play older versions of minecraft for the sake of the mods they can run feels like an upgrade rather than a sacrifice. With regards to your point about the popularity of the game, I think you're right about the game peaking in popularity for now, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. People like Dream and Pewdiepie brought the game back into the spotlight, but there's always been a community of people that sticks by the game just for the fun of it, no matter how it's faring with YouTube's algorithm. The folks from Hermitcraft come to mind. TL;DR, don't worry too much about Mojang or popular Youtubers, more often than not the community can supply what they can't or won't. There are certainly things to worry about, like the kerfuffle with Microsoft account migration, but I doubt we'll see minecraft truly die off for a good long time.

People like Dream and Pewdiepie brought the game back into the spotlight, but there's always been a community of people that sticks by the game just for the fun of it, no matter how it's faring with YouTube's algorithm. body:
> The bible often places an emphasis on the importance of strong leadership.

No, church and national tradition is what emphasizes "strong leadership" and those are two of the biggest enemies to believers in every part of the bible. If you are truly right, then why do you need the power to stomp out opposition? It wouldn't be a threat to you! Nearly every major conflict in the whole bible is caused by those in power, we have Pharaoh, then the Canaanites and the evil kings of Israel and Judah (and even the good ones didn't have it together), then the Babylonians, then the Pharisees and the Roman government, and a whole bunch of other stuff. They are even responsible for the crucifixion. It's always the same pattern: someone in power feels threatened by Christians and tries to execute the final solution. Even writers who try to portray Jewish kings as favorably as possible admit that having one at all was the result of idolatrous people literally demanding it (1 Samuel 8). Humans are tribal animals, and both wanting to attain power and dominion for yourself and idolizing those above you are some of the most basic social instincts. This is why we see people worshiping celebrities and politicians and even popular people in their own circle to the point of absurdity. This is why they value conformity above all else and reflexively coerce offenders back into line. But the flesh and the spirit are opposed to one another!

> It doesn't even say we should do these various things *more to leaders

This verse most definitely implies it. If the writer does not set aside leaders as special then why the need to elaborate specifically on them so much?

> instead of advocating for leaders to be accepted into position without question, 1 Timothy gives at least 10-11 requirements for the status of overseer.

Yes, to make sure leaders are approved of by the author of 1 Timothy. He wouldn't want his own system to backfire on him by placing people he doesn't like in power! Of course the simple solution to avoid all this mess is to just follow Jesus's advice in Matthew 23.

parent.body:
What it says is: I urge that supplications, prayers, intercessions, and thanksgivings be made for all people, for kings and all who are in high positions, that we may lead a peaceful and quiet life, godly and dignified in every way.

The bible often places an emphasis on the importance of strong leadership. I don't see how telling the populace to remember to pray to those who lead would be contrary to its message. It doesn't even say we should do these various things *more to leaders, and instead of advocating for leaders to be accepted into position without question, 1 Timothy gives at least 10-11 requirements for the status of overseer.

post.body:
Pride is one of the "seven deadly sins" and biblically has no association to the rainbow. Thus I've dubbed the past several years June, in which the rainbow becomes plastered everywhere, as Promise Month in order to spread the good word of a promise made by God never again to flood the earth. To take a hand made symbol given to us by God and pervert it into something that represents something He calls abominable is a horrible thing. In my opinion not even the cross is as intimate as the rainbow, as the cross itself had no power on its own, but the blood of Christ was what brought redemption, not two pieces of wood. The rainbow, however, was hand crafted by the Father for us.

I say wear the rainbow this month and emblazon it with the word PROMISE. When people ask you why it doesn't say pride, explain to them, and spread the gospel a bit. Take back what was given to those who follow the way of truth.
